    1. filePath

Annotation Interface Configuration

@Retention(RUNTIME) @Target(TYPE) public @interface Configuration
Marks a class with the location of a properties (configuration) file to be used when binding property values to fields annotated with PropertyKey.

Apply this annotation to a configuration holder class to declare which properties file (relative to the application's resources root / classpath) contains the values that should be injected into fields annotated with @PropertyKey.

Semantics

  • The filePath value is treated as a path relative to the runtime classpath/resources root. For example, "qa-configurations.properties" refers to /resources/qa-configurations.properties.
  • Retention is RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME so annotation processors or reflection-based binders can discover it at runtime.
  • This annotation targets ElementType.TYPE (classes and interfaces). It is typically placed on simple POJOs that act as containers for configuration values.

Placeholder variables in filePath

The filePath may include simple placeholder variables of the form ${KEY}. A binding/reader implementation can resolve these placeholders before attempting to load the resource by using the utility in PlaceholderResolver (see PlaceholderResolver.resolvePlaceholders(String)).

Resolution behavior (as implemented by PlaceholderResolver): resolution first checks Java system properties (System.getProperty), then environment variables (System.getenv). If a placeholder key is not found an IllegalArgumentException is thrown by the resolver. The annotation itself does not perform placeholder resolution â€” callers must explicitly invoke the resolver or a reader that does so.

Example


 @Configuration(filePath = "${env}-configurations.properties")
 public class TestConfiguration { ... }

 // A reader/binder might perform:
 String resolvedPath = PlaceholderResolver.resolvePlaceholders(TestConfiguration.class.getAnnotation(Configuration.class).filePath());
 // then load resolvedPath from the classpath

Notes & best practices

  • Prefer a stable, predictable path structure under src/main/resources to avoid ambiguity across environments.
  • When multiple configuration files exist (profiles/environments), keep them in separate directories (e.g. env/dev/, env/prod/).
  • Document how the binder resolves missing files and how PropertyKey.defaultValue() interacts with absent or empty properties.
  • If you rely on placeholder resolution, ensure the environment variable or system property used by the placeholder is set in the runtime environment; otherwise PlaceholderResolver will throw an exception.
See Also:

    Required Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Required Element

  • Element Details

    • filePath

      String filePath
      Returns:
      File path relative to the application's resources/classpath root.

      The returned string may contain simple placeholders of the form ${KEY}. Consumers (for example a PropertiesReader or other binder) that support placeholders should pass this value through PlaceholderResolver.resolvePlaceholders(String) before attempting to locate and load the resource. Missing placeholder keys will result in an IllegalArgumentException from the resolver.
